content.question: For parts of the free response question that require calculations, clearly show the method used and the steps involved in arriving at your answers. You must show your work to receive credit for your answer. Examples and equations may be included in your answers where appropriate.For parts of the free response question that require calculations, clearly show the method used and the steps involved in arriving at your answers. You must show your work to receive credit for your answer. Examples and equations may be included in your answers where appropriate.Answer the following questions related to manganese compounds.(a) Manganese has several common oxidation states.(i) Write the complete electron configuration for an <math alttext="M n" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>Mn</mi></math> atom in the ground state.

frqParts.text: For parts of the free response question that require calculations, clearly show the method used and the steps involved in arriving at your answers. You must show your work to receive credit for your answer. Examples and equations may be included in your answers where appropriate.For parts of the free response question that require calculations, clearly show the method used and the steps involved in arriving at your answers. You must show your work to receive credit for your answer. Examples and equations may be included in your answers where appropriate.Answer the following questions related to manganese compounds.(a) Manganese has several common oxidation states.(i) Write the complete electron configuration for an <math alttext="M n" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>Mn</mi></math> atom in the ground state.
(ii) When manganese forms cations, electrons are lost from which subshell first? Identify both the number and letter associated with the subshell.

A student performs an experiment to produce a manganese salt of unknown composition, <math alttext="M n sub x, end sub, C l sub y, end sub, aqueous" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mn>Mn</mn><mn>x</mn></msub><msub><mn>Cl</mn><mn>y</mn></msub><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></math>, and determine its empirical formula. The student places a sample of <math alttext="M n, solid " display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>Mn</mtext><mfenced><mi>s</mi></mfenced></math> in a beaker containing excess <math alttext="H C l, aqueous" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>HCl</mi><mfenced><mrow><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi></mrow></mfenced></math>, as represented by the following equation.<math alttext="x M n, solid, plus y H C l, aqueous, reacts to produce, M n, sub x, end sub, C l, sub y, end sub, aqueous, plus the fraction y over 2, end fraction, H 2, gas" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mo> </mo><mo> </mo><mtext>Mn</mtext><mfenced><mi>s</mi></mfenced><mo>+</mo><mi>y</mi><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mi>HCl</mi><mfenced><mrow><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi></mrow></mfenced><mo>→</mo><msub><mn>Mn</mn><mn>x</mn></msub><msub><mn>Cl</mn><mn>y</mn></msub><mfenced><mrow><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi></mrow></mfenced><mo>+</mo><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mfrac><mi>y</mi><mn>2</mn></mfrac></mstyle><mo> </mo><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mfenced><mi>g</mi></mfenced></math>The student heats the resulting mixture until only <math alttext="M n sub x, end sub, C l sub y, end sub, solid " display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>Mn</mtext><mn>x</mn></msub><msub><mn>Cl</mn><mn>y</mn></msub><mfenced><mi>s</mi></mfenced></math> remains in the beaker. The data are given in the following table.Mass of empty beaker<math alttext="60.169 grams" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>60.169</mn><mo> </mo><mi mathvariant="normal">g</mi></math>Mass of beaker and <math alttext="M n, solid" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>Mn</mtext><mfenced><mi>s</mi></mfenced></math> <math alttext="61.262 grams" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>61.262</mn><mo> </mo><mi mathvariant="normal">g</mi></math>Mass of beaker and <math alttext="M n sub x, end sub, C l sub y, end sub " display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>Mn</mi><mi>x</mi></msub><msub><mi>Cl</mi><mi>y</mi></msub></math> after heating to constant mass <math alttext="62.673 grams" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>62.673</mn><mo> </mo><mi mathvariant="normal">g</mi></math>(b) Calculate the mass of <math alttext="C l" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>Cl</mi></math> in the sample of <math alttext="M n sub x, end sub, C l sub y, end sub, solid" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mn>Mn</mn><mn>x</mn></msub><msub><mn>Cl</mn><mn>y</mn></msub><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></math> remaining in the beaker.

(c) Calculate the number of moles of <math alttext="C l" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>Cl</mi></math> in the sample of <math alttext="M n sub x, end sub, C l sub y, end sub, solid " display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>Mn</mtext><mn>x</mn></msub><msub><mn>Cl</mn><mn>y</mn></msub><mfenced><mi>s</mi></mfenced></math> remaining in the beaker.

(d) The student determines that <math alttext="0.0199 mole" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>0.0199</mn><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>mol</mtext></math> of <math alttext="M n" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>Mn</mi></math> was used in the experiment. Use the data to determine the empirical formula of the <math alttext="M n sub x, end sub, C l sub y, end sub, solid" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>Mn</mtext><mn>x</mn></msub><msub><mn>Cl</mn><mn>y</mn></msub><mfenced><mi>s</mi></mfenced></math>.

(e) The student repeats the experiment using the same amounts of <math alttext="M n" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>Mn</mi></math> and <math alttext="H C l" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>HCl</mi></math> and notices that some of the <math alttext=" M n sub x, end sub, C l sub y, end sub" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>Mn</mtext><mn>x</mn></msub><msub><mn>Cl</mn><mn>y</mn></msub></math> splatters out of the beaker as it is heated to dryness. Will the number of moles of <math alttext="C l" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>Cl</mi></math> calculated for this trial be greater than, less than, or equal to the number calculated in part (c) ? Justify your answer.

(f) Another compound of manganese, <math alttext="M n O 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>Mn</mtext><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math>, is used in alkaline batteries, represented by the following diagram. Some half-reactions are given in the table.(i) Based on the half-reactions given in the table, write the balanced net ionic equation for the reaction that has the greatest thermodynamic favorability.

(ii) Calculate the value of <math alttext="E naught sub cell" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msubsup><mi>E</mi><mrow><mi>c</mi><mi>e</mi><mi>l</mi><mi>l</mi></mrow><mo>°</mo></msubsup></math> for the overall reaction.

(iii) Calculate the value of <math alttext="delta G naught" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>Δ</mtext><msup><mi>G</mi><mo>°</mo></msup></math> in <math alttext="kilojoules per mole reaction" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>kJ/mol</mtext><mrow><mi>r</mi><mi>x</mi><mi>n</mi></mrow></msub></math>.
(iv) A student claims that the total mass of an alkaline battery decreases as the battery operates because the anode loses mass. Do you agree with the student’s claim? Justify your answer.

skill.text: 3.B: Represent chemical substances or phenomena with appropriate diagrams or models (e.g., electron configuration).
